contents:
The stream was too wide for us to jump across. We saw a foot-log and
 decided to try it. It was narrow, but Abe said, “Let's do it.” He was like that; 
he would take a chance if it was important to do something. He went first and
 reached the other side all right. I went about half way across, when I slipped. 
He shouted, “Don't look down nor up nor sideways, but look right at me and 
hold on tight!” But I fell off into the creek and the water was about seven or 
eight feet deep. I could not swim, and neither could Abe. I was splashing and 
calling out. He got a stick and climbed out and held it out to me. I came up, 
grabbing with both hands, and he put the stick into my hands. I clung to it, and 
he pulled me out on the bank, almost dead. He got me by the arms and shook 
me well. Then he rolled me on the ground, and the water poured out of my 
mouth. I was all right very soon.
